thread.title: Sammy Batten: Appalachian State has best midseason report card
thread.title_full: Sammy Batten: Appalachian State has best midseason report card

title: Sammy Batten: Appalachian State has best midseason report card
text:
Sammy Batten: Appalachian State has best midseason report card 
Wasn’t it just a week or so ago that North Carolina and South Carolina played in Charlotte to kick off the 2015 college football season? 
It seems like it, but low and behold here we are already at the halfway point of the year. Thus, it seems an appropriate time to submit my midseason 
report card on North Carolina’s seven Football Bowl Subdivision teams. 
Appalachian State (A+) — The Mountaineers were clearly out of their league against Clemson, but otherwise have performed exactly as expected in rising to the top of the Sun Belt Conference standings. Thursday’s triumph over Georgia Southern was huge. 
Charlotte (C+) — After opening with two straight wins, the 49ers have now lost four straight. But they were competitive in their first two Conference USA outings, losing to Florida Atlantic and Old Dominion by just 13 total points. 
Duke (A) — The Blue Devils are no longer a fluke, and they’ve proven it again by riding a stellar defense to a share of first place in the ACC Coastal Division. So far, Duke has exceeded preseason expectations that had it finishing fourth in the Coastal. 
East Carolina (B) — The Pirates could have gotten a much higher grade, but so many narrow losses, especially to Navy and Temple in American Athletic Conference play, knocked them down several notches. 
N.C. State (B) — The Wolfpack got my hopes up with its 4-0 start, then disappointed by opening ACC play with two straight setbacks. I picked N.C. State to finish third in the ACC Atlantic Division, so at this stage it’s not met expectations. But State has always been a second-half team, so the best may be ahead. 
North Carolina (A-) — Boy, if only UNC had won that opener against South Carolina, which it should have done. The Tar Heels have positioned themselves to compete for the ACC Coastal title. Not bad for a team picked to finish fifth in the preseason poll. 
Wake Forest (C+) — Overachieving at times, like against Florida State, and underachieving at others (UNC) was the pattern in the first half for the Deacons. Their three wins probably exceeded expectations, but not by much. 
And for the first-half individual awards: 
Coach of the Mid-Year: Appalachian State’s Scott Satterfield, Duke’s David Cutcliffe and UNC’s Larry Fedora all deserve mention. But ECU’s Ruffin McNeill has dealt with losing his starting quarterback and still kept the Pirates winning. 
Offensive Player: A toss-up between Appalachian State running back Marcus Cox and N.C. State’s Matt Dayes. 
Defensive Player: No contest. Duke safety Jeremy Cash has been simply dominant. 
Staff writer Sammy Batten can be reached at battens@fayobserver.com or 486-3534.
